prior_works.title: The Stability of Hedonic Coalition Structures
prior_works.role: Foundational theory of hedonic games and single-agent stability
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces core stability notions for hedonic games, including individual and Nash stability based on single-agent deviations; the paper’s "local stability" adapts these deviation-based ideas to the friend/enemy setting and guides its algorithmic local-improvement framework.

prior_works.title: Core in a Simple Coalition Formation Game
prior_works.authors: Soma Banerjee, Hideo Konishi, Tayfun Sönmez
prior_works.role: Foundational model of hedonic coalition formation
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Establishes the hedonic coalition formation framework and core concepts underpinning coalition-based partitioning; this provides the conceptual backbone for interpreting clusterings as stable partitions over agents’ preferences.

prior_works.title: Hedonic Games with Graph-Restricted Communication
prior_works.role: Graph-based representation and stability/complexity in hedonic games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Shows how communication/interaction graphs compactly encode feasible coalitions and affect stability and complexity; the paper’s friendship/enemy graph representation is a signed-graph specialization that builds directly on graph-restricted hedonic modeling.

prior_works.title: Fractional Hedonic Games
prior_works.authors: Haris Aziz, Felix Brandt, Hans Georg Seedig
prior_works.role: Valuation via social graphs and algorithmic stability in hedonic games
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Models agents’ utilities from coalition mates via weighted social ties and studies existence/complexity of Nash/individual stability; this directly motivates mapping similarity/dissimilarity edges to preferences and designing efficient local-deviation algorithms.

prior_works.title: Correlation Clustering
prior_works.authors: Nikhil Bansal, Avrim Blum, Shuchi Chawla
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Formalizes clustering from signed (agree/disagree) edges and popularizes local-improvement heuristics; the paper’s friend/enemy graphs and its algorithmic goals mirror correlation clustering’s signed-graph view and motivate single-vertex move procedures.

prior_works.title: Near Linear Time Algorithm to Detect Community Structures in Large-Scale Networks
prior_works.authors: Usha Nandini Raghavan, Réka Albert, Soundar Kumara
prior_works.role: Local, single-node update paradigm for community detection
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Introduces the label propagation algorithm, a prototypical single-node, majority-based local update scheme; this directly inspires the paper’s single-agent deviation mechanisms for finding locally popular/stable partitions at scale.

prior_works.title: Community Detection in Networks with Positive and Negative Links
prior_works.relationship_sentence: Demonstrates how to cluster when edges encode friendship and enmity, aligning with structural balance; this supports the paper’s signed-graph modeling of preferences and its application to community detection with both similarities and dissimilarities.

synthesis_narrative:
The paper’s core contribution—casting clustering as coalition formation in hedonic games with explicit friendship and enmity graphs and designing efficient local-deviation algorithms—sits at the confluence of two lines of work. From the hedonic-games literature, Banerjee–Konishi–Sönmez (2001) and Bogomolnaia–Jackson (2002) provide the foundational framework and deviation-based stability concepts (individual/Nash stability) that the paper adapts into its notions of local stability and local popularity for partitions. Subsequent work on algorithmic and representational aspects of hedonic games, especially Aziz–Brandt–Seedig (2014) on fractional hedonic games, shows how preferences can be encoded via weighted social ties and how stability/complexity trade-offs arise—directly motivating the paper’s compact, graph-based preference model and its complexity analysis.
On the clustering side, Bansal–Blum–Chawla (2004) established correlation clustering, which formalizes the friend/enemy (agree/disagree) view central to this paper’s mapping from similarity/dissimilarity to preferences, and legitimizes local-search style procedures. Raghavan–Albert–Kumara (2007) further influenced the algorithmic design through single-node label updates, a blueprint for efficient, scalable local improvement driven by neighborhood relations. Bridging these domains, Igarashi–Elkind (2016) demonstrated that graph-restricted hedonic games offer compact preference representations with tractable algorithms in certain cases, while Traag–Bruggeman (2009) validated the importance of signed networks for community detection. Collectively, these works directly inform the paper’s modeling choices (signed friendship/enemy graphs), stability notions (single-agent deviations), algorithmic mechanisms (local updates), and empirical focus (clustering and community detection).
